verses.text: In the third year of Hoshea son of Elah, king of Israel, Hezekiah the son of Ahaz, king of Judah, began to reign.
verses.comment: Names and dates match Hebrew text. Intro timing per standard form.

verses.text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Abi, the daughter of Zechariah.
verses.comment: Name 'Abi' from Hebrew; sometimes rendered Abijah.

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, just as his father David had done.
verses.comment: Standard phrase in Kings for good kings. 'His father' = ancestor.

verses.text: He removed the high places, broke the pillars, cut down the Asherah, and broke in pieces the bronze serpent that Moses had made, because until those days the people of Israel had been burning incense to it—it was called Nehushtan.
verses.comment: Close to Hebrew order; 'Asherah' left untranslated (sacred pole/wooden idol).

verses.text: He trusted in the Lord, the God of Israel; there was no one like him among all the kings of Judah, neither before him nor after him.
verses.comment: Superlative from Hebrew rendered literal.

verses.text: For he clung to the Lord; he did not turn away from following him, but kept his commandments, which the Lord commanded Moses.
verses.comment: 'Clung' (dabaq) directly rendered.

verses.text: And the Lord was with him; wherever he went out, he succeeded. He rebelled against the king of Assyria and did not serve him.
verses.comment: Succinct Hebrew—kept form.

verses.text: He defeated the Philistines as far as Gaza and its territory, from the watchtower to the fortified city.
verses.comment: 'Watchtower' = outpost, literal translation.

verses.text: In the fourth year of King Hezekiah, which was the seventh year of Hoshea son of Elah, king of Israel, Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against Samaria and besieged it.
verses.comment: Chronological coordination with Israel.

verses.text: At the end of three years they captured it. In the sixth year of Hezekiah, which was the ninth year of Hoshea king of Israel, Samaria was taken.
verses.comment: Maintains exact dating as in original.

verses.text: The king of Assyria carried the Israelites away to Assyria and placed them in Halah, and on the Habor, the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.
verses.comment: Geographical terms kept as-is.

verses.text: Because they did not listen to the voice of the Lord their God but transgressed his covenant, all that Moses the servant of the Lord commanded—they neither listened nor obeyed.
verses.comment: Double emphasis 'listened nor obeyed' directly rendered.

verses.text: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

Hezekiah king of Judah sent word to the king of Assyria at Lachish, saying, 'I have done wrong; withdraw from me. Whatever you impose on me, I will bear.' And the king of Assyria imposed on Hezekiah king of Judah a tribute of three hundred talents of silver and thirty talents of gold.
verses.comment: Direct speech preserved as in Hebrew.

verses.text: So Hezekiah gave him all the silver that was found in the house of the Lord and in the treasuries of the king's house.
At that time Hezekiah stripped the gold from the doors of the temple of the Lord, and from the doorposts that he, King Hezekiah, had overlaid, and gave it to the king of Assyria.

Then the king of Assyria sent the Tartan, the Rabsaris, and the Rabshakeh with a great army from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. And they went up and came to Jerusalem. They came and stood by the conduit of the upper pool, which is on the road to the Launderer's Field.
verses.comment: Official titles left as transliterations: 'Tartan', 'Rabsaris', 'Rabshakeh'.

verses.text: When they called for the king, Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder, went out to them.
And the Rabshakeh said to them, 'Say to Hezekiah, “Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: In what are you trusting, that you remain so confident?”'
verses.comment: Speech formatted as direct quote.

verses.text: You say, “But they are only empty words: ‘I have counsel and strength for war.’” Now, in whom are you trusting, that you have rebelled against me?
verses.comment: Phrase 'empty words' (literally 'a word of the lips') modernized.

verses.text: Look, you are trusting now in Egypt, that broken reed of a staff, which will pierce the hand of anyone who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who trust in him.
verses.comment: Metaphor preserved as in Hebrew.

verses.text: But if you say to me, 'We trust in the Lord our God,' is it not he whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem, 'You must worship before this altar in Jerusalem'?
verses.comment: Assyrian misunderstanding of Hezekiah's reforms presented as in text.

verses.text: Come, now, make a wager with my master the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able, on your part, to set riders on them.
How then can you turn back even one official of the least of my master’s servants, when you put your trust in Egypt for chariots and horsemen?
Moreover, is it without the Lord that I have come up against this place to destroy it? The Lord said to me, ‘Go up against this land and destroy it.’”
verses.comment: Direct quote; Assyrian claiming divine sanction.

verses.text: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, and Shebna, and Joah said to Rabshakeh, 'Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it. Do not speak with us in the language of Judah within the hearing of the people who are on the wall.'
verses.comment: 'Language of Judah' = Hebrew.

verses.text: But the Rabshakeh said to them, 'Has my master sent me to your master and to you only, and not to the men sitting on the wall, who are doomed with you to eat their own dung and to drink their own urine?'
verses.comment: Graphic phrase rendered literally, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Then the Rabshakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in the language of Judah, 'Hear the word of the great king, the king of Assyria!'
Thus says the king: ‘Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you from my hand.’
Do not let Hezekiah make you trust in the Lord by saying, “The Lord will surely deliver us, and this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.”

Do not listen to Hezekiah. For thus says the king of Assyria: 'Make peace with me and come out to me. Then each one of you will eat from his own vine and his own fig tree, and drink water from his own cistern,
verses.comment: 'Make peace' (literally 'make a blessing') idiom rendered for clarity.

verses.text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards, a land of olive trees and honey, that you may live and not die. But do not listen to Hezekiah when he misleads you by saying, “The Lord will deliver us.”
verses.comment: Full agricultural phrase preserved.

verses.text: Has any of the gods of the nations ever delivered his land from the hand of the king of Assyria?
Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah? Have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?
verses.comment: All place names rendered as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Who among all the gods of these lands has delivered their land out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?'
But the people remained silent and answered him not a word, for the king’s command was, 'Do not answer him.'

Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.
verses.comment: Tearing clothes = mourning; standard translation.
